content:
Yes, there are some Hebrew words that are believed to have a clear Punic origin. A few examples are:

1. נֶצַח (netzach) - meaning "victory" or "eternity." This word appears in the Hebrew Bible and is likely derived from the Punic word "neṭaḥ" which means "to win" or "to succeed."

2. פֶּאֱגָה (pe'egah) - meaning "suddenly" or "in a moment." This word also appears in the Bible and is believed to come from the Punic word "pe'eg" which means "foot" or "step."

3. שִׁטְפוֹן (shitfon) - meaning "whirlwind" or "storm." The origin of this word is uncertain, but it is thought to be related to the Punic word "shtpn" which means "violent wind."

4. מִלְחָמָה (milchama) - meaning "war." This word appears often in the Hebrew Bible, and it is believed to be derived from the Punic word "mlk" which means "to fight."

Overall, the influence of Punic on Hebrew is not entirely clear, but there are several words shared between the two languages that suggest a close relationship.
